Someday I'm going to have a real studio with proper lighting so I'm not painting in my own shadow at 4:30 in the morning 🫤 

#oilpainter #oilpainters #artistslife

Framed prints are available in my online shop as well as canvas prints, metal and acrylic block 🎄Link in my bio. 

I will be closing this shop permanently on Dec. 30. Most of these prints will never be available again. 

#horseart #animalart #fineart #fineartprints #holidaygifts

"Burro 66 Emerald" a recent commissioned piece with @marshallgallery for a wonderful collector. 

At the start I was a little unsure about the requested green & brown color palette but I absolutely love the way it turned out. In person, this donkey piece looks like a little jeweled emerald. 

Big thanks to my talented partner in crime @gypsyartisan for custom creating another gorgeous floater frame.

Wishing you all a happy New Year! ✨🥂🎉 I want to start this year off by thanking you so much for following and supporting my art. It means the world to me 💛

My creative goals for the new year are to upgrade my studio, focus on larger works, make time to experiment more and forge new ways to combat the loneliness and isolation of painting full time. 

I would also like to improve my IG account. Is there anything you would like to request or see this year? 

#oilpainter #oilpaintersofinstagram #oilpaintersoninstagram #artistsoninstagram #artistslife

Abstract verticals

Why? Because I like the way it looks when paint rains down on my horses ☔️

Creating not copying is scary. Fear of failure is real and hovers over me constantly. Pushing through it to attempt to get to something new. 

Last day of work on "Red Stag" 48x60 oil on panel.

#oilpainting #oilpainters #oilpaintersofamerica #oilpaintingtechniques #fearoffailure #createyourlife #createart #contemporaryart #abstractrealism #contemporarywesternart #painterslife

A little #tbt post today and brief introduction for new followers. Hi, I'm Harper. I was born in Idaho. I lived in CA and then New England for most of my life and now Arizona is where I call home. 

I've been painting professionally for 5 years. Before that I was a graphic designer & art director for 30 years. I earned my BFA in Illustration from Paier College. I was trained in realism but grew tired of feeling like I was just copying reference and wanted to put more of myself into my work so I began experimenting with abstraction.

I am married to my partner in crime @gypsyartisan and I have one daughter, Emma who is 24 (yikes! when did that happen?)

The little guy with me in the pic is my 15 year old Lhasa Poo, Coco who is my constant and devoted studio companion. We are in front of "Equus Ombre" 36x36 oil.

Thank you all so much for joining me on my art journey. Your presence here, friendship and support have meant the world to me 🫶 As many of you may know, painting is lonely business. I really welcome your comments & questions... or even when you just drop-in to say hi 🤠

Hugs, Harper

If you're a wild horse lover, trust me... you will want to listen to the latest episode of Dirt Road Discussions podcast. It's all about the infamous White Horse of Black Daisy Canyon and the guest speaker is my aunt Barbara! You can find it wherever you like to listen to podcasts. Keep reading below for a little more about this episode.

I'm trying to convince aunt Barbara to start a podcast of her own. She's got enough western stories for probably 300 episodes. After you listen, come back here and tell me if you liked it.

Once thought to be a wild horse that was domesticated, the White Horse of Black Daisy Canyon is said to have escaped a hunting camp 25 years ago and has since survived on its own back in the rugged mountains around Mackay, Idaho. Locals and out-of-towners watch every spring for this icon to reappear to add to the White Horse's longevity and legacy. Macky resident and White Horse admirer, Barbara Harp, tells us this amazing story and how they know it is the same horse.

#wildhorses #wildhorse #horselover #wildhorsesofinstagram #wildhorsesofidaho #idaho #idahoexplored #idaholife #dirtroad #dirtroadtherapy #dirtroadlife #dirtroaddiscussions

Cowgirl Up! Exhibition & Sale @westernmuseum is almost here. These are my six new paintings that will be in this year's show. Tickets for Opening Weekend are still available > link in my bio. After that the show stays open to the public through Sept 3. Keep reading for more info about this incredible show.

In 2006, Desert Caballeros Western Museum embraced a revolutionary idea: an annual exhibition showcasing the brightest contemporary female artists working in the Western genre. In the male-dominated world of Western Art, Cowgirl Up! turned the spotlight squarely on women’s voices and perspectives, serving up a new, deeper understanding of the American West. Over a decade later, CU! remains one of the major national events for Western women artists.

Your purchase of original artworks supports the endeavors of women artists working today and of the Desert Caballeros Western Museum. CU! art can be bought throughout the run of the exhibition at the Museum or online at westernmuseum.org.

Full transparency - with this piece I have made the decision to bow out of any future art auctions. Emerging artists thinking auctions are everything you might want to keep reading.

Last night this 16x20 original painting sold for $1,150. I will get 70% of that. After deducting my framing costs (including my damaged frame debacle), shipping and supplies - I will have made a $200 profit on this piece. I did not even figure in the multitude of hours I spent painting it. 

If you've had good luck at auctions. Congratulations. You've probably made a name for yourself. For the rest of us that are trying hard, it's become a way to steal great art at "name your price" discounts. 

In simple terms, the collectors are going to shoot themselves in the foot by not even bidding the artist's lowest estimate. Which most have carefully calculated to cover their costs, the museum's cut and make a livable profit. They come in so far under the estimate, they will make these fundraising auction events a thing of the past. Artists will not be able to afford to participate. 

Harper

"Burro 66 Roja" 36x36 oil. A more colorful version of my favorite donkey. Why did I paint him again? Because I am painting about 8 new pieces for my first solo show ever and I really wanted my good friend here to be one of them 🧡 My solo show @victorycontemporary in Santa Fe opens June 2. I will be there in person. Some pretty cool new pieces are coming up in the next month. Stay tuned!

Another new piece for my solo show @victorycontemporary in Santa Fe on June 2. "She Waits (Minnehaha)" 30x40 oil. Keep reading for artists notes.  #abstractrealism 

The inspiration behind this piece is an iconic Photocrome print from 1904 by the Detroit Photographic Co. 

Minnehaha (Lakota) was a fictional Native American character from the 1855 epic poem written by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow "The Song of Hiawatha".

In their tragic love story, Minnehaha waits by the shore for her lover Hiawatha to return. 

The poem itself was a very successful and somewhat controversial, Europeanized retelling of Ojibwe tales. 
In the end, the poem managed to bring positive attention to the Ojibwe people in the mid 1800's and helped spur the preservation of some elements of their culture. 

I chose to reinvent this vintage image because I loved the romanticism and illustrative narrative to this young native woman looking and waiting for her lover to return. 

As with all of my Native American inspired work, with the sale of this piece, I will be making another donation to Sovereign Bodies Institute (link in my bio).

#westernart #westernartist #illustration #illustrationart #vintageart #contemporarywesternart #artofthewest #southwestart #westernartcollector #arizonaartist

Guys this is my last available 2023 Cowgirl Up Show piece @westernmuseum . Not only do I want it to go to a good home but if it doesn't sell I will have to make a road trip all the way to Wickenburg to pick up one piece. So please help me out and tag the Appaloosa horse lover in your life and together lets find Cochise a forever home!

"She Waits (Minnehaha)" 40x30 oil is available @victorycontemporary #santafe 

This contemporary western piece pays homage to an iconic Photocrome print from 1904. Minnehaha (Lakota) was a fictional Native American character from the 1855 epic poem written by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow "The Song of Hiawatha". In their tragic love story, Minnehaha waits by the shore for her lover Hiawatha to return.
 
The poem itself was a very successful and somewhat controversial, Europeanized retelling of Ojibwe tales. In the end, the poem managed to bring positive attention to the Ojibwe people in the mid 1800's and helped spur the preservation of some elements of their culture. 

As with all of my Native American inspired work, with the sale of this piece, I will be making another donation to Sovereign Bodies Institute (link in my bio if you would like to make a donation).

More WestxKlimt is coming. Are you ready?

#klimtstyle #contemporaryart #contemporarypainting #contemporaryartist #contemporarywesternart #contemporarywestern #goldpainting #westernartcollector

Why am I spending so much time and being so meticulous on this painting? Because when you're trying to tap into the creative energies that powered Gustav Klimt, I'm thinking great attention to quality and design must be observed. 

So far this WestxKlimt piece in progress has clocked approximately 80 hrs. Some of Klimt's most famous works took him 1-3 years to complete. I can't even imagine.

This piece will be revealed soon. It will be headed to the grand opening of @westerlyart in Steamboat Springs. More details coming soon.

#gustavklimt #klimtstyle #goldartwork #contemporarypainting #contemporaryart #contemporaryartist

"Burro and Baby In Gold" 36x36 oil, 24kt gold & gold gilding on wood panel. Did I mention how much I love donkeys? 

A ton of heart, soul and hours went into this one. This is my 7th Klimt styled western piece. My inspiration for this series materialized when I realized that the Wild West and some of Gustav Klimt's greatest work had one interesting thing in common - gold. More pieces coming.

This piece will be available @westerlyart grand opening #steamboatsprings see their account for details. 

With the sale of this piece I will be making another donation to a donkey rescue organization. If you'd like to make a donation now > link in my bio.

"Portrait of a Bear in Gold" 48x48 oil, 24kt gold leaf & gold gilding. 

The latest piece in my KlimtxWest series just coming off the easel. 

This piece took 3 weeks to complete. Too long in my estimation but very quick compared to a Klimt timeline. His "Woman In Gold" (properly titled "Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I") took over 4 years to complete.

What is KlimtxWest? It's the name I'm calling this series. It's a fusion of the early 1900s golden era style paintings of Austrian symbolist Gustav Klimt combined with subject matter from the American West.

How did I come up with this collab? Gold is the thing that ties them both together in my mind.

From the very earliest human discoveries of gold, the precious metal was known to be something rare and special. From Ancient Egypt, Medieval and Incan cultures through early Christian eras, gold was used to symbolize godliness, power, wealth & prestige. Fast forward to the late 1840's gold rush that stampeded across the American West.

I was curious what this crossover might look like, so I decided to paint it.

This painting will be coming soon to @marshallgallery along with two more original KlimtxWest pieces.

Only 4 spots left for my Abstract Realism workshop @scottsdaleartschool 😳 I'm in disbelief! Thank you to all who have registered. This class maxes out at 15. 

This is an in-person, one day workshop at the legendary Scottsdale Artists' School in Scottsdale, AZ. Nov. 4,  9-4pm.

Class description:
This workshop will explore the stylistic possibilities of fusing Abstract with Realism. It will encourage you to see your art differently. Discovering the artistic benefits of adding abstraction to your realistic work as a way to achieve movement, an eye-catching style or a sense of the unexpected. Harper will bring one of her current paintings in progress for examination and discussion. Students will bring a painting already in progress with their reference to work on in class. The painting should be at "drawing stage" on a lightly toned canvas or panel of any size. There will be open forum discussion, painting demonstration and individual instruction. Oil or acrylic.

If you'd like to register > link in my bio.

I will be offering an identical workshop again on April 20, 2024.

Don't shrink your vision

Boldly stare into the face of failure and create something they've never seen before.

"Portrait of a Bear in Gold" 48x48 oil & gold leaf on panel.  KlimtxWest 
Available in January @marshallgallery 

#abstractrealism #contemporarywesternart #klimtstyle

How hard could it be?

A commissioned copy is when a collector pays you to recreate a painting from one of your original paintings. 

Top 4 reasons why this is extremely difficult:

1. Inspiration, creativity & intuitive painting gets replaced by reproduction, precision & intense color matching. 

2. Size alterations. Often the collector requests the commission to be larger or smaller than the original which means in addition to copying you now have to rescale and adjust.

3. Mark making replication. You've got to convincingly recreate marks and paint strokes that were made quickly and intuitively in the original.

4. Expectations. With the nature of painting it's impossible to exactly duplicate an original work of art but there is an unspoken pressure to come as close as possible. This unrealistic goal weighs heavy on you throughout the entire recreation process.
 
So why do it? 

I don't often accept this type of commission. I did in this case because I was told the collectors were particularly enamored by the original but the price was outside their budget. 

I guess sometimes it just comes down to your love and appreciation for your collectors. Feeling good knowing that you recreated a piece for them that they will bring into their home and cherish.

"Fierro II" 24x24 oil on canvas

"Fierro" original 48x48 is currently available @marshallgallery

Today I had to say goodbye to one of the sweetest dogs I've ever had. I am absolutely wrecked 😢 Layla was 15. She will be so dearly missed 💔🐾 
#havanese

Sometimes when you have to process a really difficult event with lots of emotions the best thing you can do is throw yourself into something else. Thankfully for me today, that was Open Studio @scottsdaleartschool. I was very thankful for this pleasant distraction. We had the great pleasure of painting @gypsyartisan . I'm very rusty at portraiture with a live sitter. It's challenging but there's nothing better to improve your painting or drawing skills.

Bison In Gold

Just coming off the easel. This piece took much longer than expected. Once I got into him his size seemed to overwhelm me. I guess that probably seems about right for a giant bison. 

This will be the last of my Klimt styled golden era pieces. This series has been a valuable learning experience. I'm proud of all the unique work I've created but now I think  I'm ready to move ahead with some new ideas for the new year. 

"Bison In Gold" 48x60 oil, 24KT gold leaf and gold gilding will be available @marshallgallery on Jan 11. Please join us from 5-9pm for a group show with Roger Hayden Johnson, Shari Lyon and yours truly. I will be premiering 3 new pieces. Hope to see you there!

#arizonaartist #bisonart #klimtstyle

Many months of my life went into creating these three new paintings. They are the final pieces in my KlimtxWest series in which I have tried to pay tribute to the golden era stylings of master artist #gustavklimt using iconic images from the American west. 

All three will be available @marshallgallery in Scottsdale on 1/11/24 for a special Artwalk show featuring artists Robert Hayden Johnson, Shari Lyon and myself. 

Artists will be there to meet & greet from 5-9pm. Complimentary beverages. 

Hope to see you there!
